channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Protesters Return to Hong Kong’s Streets
item.description: Days ahead of a vote that would turn Beijing’s election plan into local law, thousands call on lawmakers to honor pledges to veto the proposal.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: South African Court Said to Block Sudan Leader’s Departure
item.description: A South African court issued an interim order to prevent President Omar Hassan al-Bashir from leaving the country after the International Criminal Court sought his arrest on genocide charges.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir at an African Union summit in Johannesburg on Sunday.

item.title: Zoo Animals on the Loose in Tbilisi After Flooding
item.description: Heavy rains destroyed the enclosures of the Georgian city’s main zoo, and at least eight people have been reported dead.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A hippopotamus in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Sunday, one of dozens of animals to escape after flooding destroyed the enclosures of the city’s main zoo.

item.title: Pope Francis to Explore Climate’s Effect on World’s Poor
item.description: When Francis releases his first major teaching letter on the theme of the environment and poverty, he may redefine a secular topic as a matter of morality.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Pope Francis May Find Wariness Among U.S. Bishops on Climate Change
item.description: American leaders of the Catholic Church, a group shaped by Francis’s conservative predecessors, are hesitant about becoming involved in a cause championed by Francis.
item.category: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Chris Lee/St. Louis Post-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Mass at the spring meeting of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops in St. Louis.

item.title: Play Set in Israeli Prison Imperils Arab Theater
item.description: The play, “Parallel Time,” explores the personal details of prison life for a Palestinian convicted of killing an Israeli soldier.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Actors preparing for “1945,” a play produced by Al-Midan Theater after one inspired by the case of a convicted murderer generated protests.

item.title: Iranian President Expects Sanctions to Lift Within Months of Deal
item.description: As the June 30 deadline for the agreement approaches, Hassan Rouhani and other Iranian leaders say talks should continue longer if necessary.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Gaza ‘Tunnel Millionaire’ Falls on Hard Times
item.description: Mohammed Sawiri is among the thousands of Palestinians who became wealthy by hauling goods through tunnels under the border with Egypt but are now struggling to survive.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Now you mock me because I am a tea seller.” —

item.title: U.S. Is Poised to Put Heavy Weaponry in Eastern Europe
item.description: The proposal, if approved, would represent the first time since the end of the Cold War that the United States has stationed heavy military equipment in Eastern Europe.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Stryker vehicles from the Army’s 2nd Cavalry Regiment took part in a military exercise in Riga, Latvia.

item.title: Australian Leader Is Pressed on Whether Migrant Smugglers Were Paid to Turn Back
item.description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott has refused to confirm or deny whether the government paid smugglers to turn a boat full of migrants back to Indonesia.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia faced questions over a boat carrying migrants.

item.title: Taliban Attack Police Base in Afghanistan, Killing 17
item.description: Afghanistan’s police force took another severe blow in the attack, which began after midnight Saturday in a strategically important district in Helmand Province.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Experts Fault South Korean Response to MERS Outbreak
item.description: The government’s failure to share information quickly contributed to worsening the outbreak, a panel that included experts from the World Health Organization said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 6 Guantánamo Detainees From Yemen Are Transferred to Oman
item.description: The move of the Yemenis, who were lower-level prisoners held for 13 years, reduces the number held at prison in Cuba to 116.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Asian Migrants Say Australia Paid Smugglers to Turn Back
item.description: The migrants’ account has stoked debate over the hard-line policy on illegal immigrants that helped Prime Minister Tony Abbott win office in 2013 but exposed Australia to pointed criticism by United Nations agencies.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and JOE COCHRANE

item.title: ISIS Is Winning the Social Media War, U.S. Concludes
item.description: An internal State Department assessment says the Islamic State’s social message machine is trumping efforts by the Obama administration and its foreign allies to combat it.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: France: Police at Airport Detain Girl, 6, for 3 Days
item.description: The airport police in Paris held a 6-year-old French girl for three days on suspicion that she had a fake passport — until a judge ordered her released into her mother’s custody.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Moldova: Premier Resigns Amid Queries on Diplomas
item.description: Moldova’s prime minister resigned on Friday after state prosecutors questioned him over his high school and university degrees.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: White House Weighs Sanctions After Second Breach of a Computer System
item.description: Officials said that the second system contained files related to intelligence officials working for the F.B.I., defense contractors and other government agencies.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Open Source: Egyptian Doctors Shame Government With Facebook Images of Filthy State-Run Hospitals
item.description: Doctors have posted hundreds of photos of patients surrounded by filth, stray cats, sewage, rodent droppings and snakes.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: An image of a cat-infested hospital room in Egypt posted on Facebook this week.

item.title: Tunisian Consular Workers Are Seized by Libyan Militia
item.description: Members of the group Libya Dawn were said to be behind the attack, in retaliation for the detention by Tunisia of their leader, Walid Qulaib.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
